district court judge has temporarily barred the Pentagon from transferring a Guantanamo detainee back home to Tunisia.
This appears to be the first ruling of its kind for a Guantanamo detainee.
The judge, Gladys Kessler, says that Mohammed Abdul Rahman cannot be sent back to Tunisia because he might suffer irreparable harm there, and the judge means torture.
NPR's national security correspondent Jackie Northam has been following this case.
She's with us now.
Jackie, what can you tell us about this particular prisoner?
Well, Mohammed Abdul Rahman, he is from Tunisia, originally.
He fled that country.
He had problems there.
He ended up in Pakistan, and that's where he was picked up by the U.S.
military and taken to Guantanamo, where he's been for about five years now.
We don't have an exact age on him.
However, we do know that he has some serious medical problems, both with his kidneys and with his heart.
The U.S.
military - the Pentagon wants to try and sent him back to Tunisia, but he's actually protesting this because he says, look, if I go back, I'm going to be tortured.
There's no question about it.
And so he does not want to go at all.
And why is it that the Pentagon wants to send him back there?
It's part of the whole effort they're trying to do to clear the numbers at Guantanamo.
Right now, there are 80 detainees that are cleared to go back to their home countries, and Mr. Rahman is one of them.
The problem is in some cases like his is that the detainees do not want to go.
Mr. Rahman was tried in absentia, and he faces 20 years of prison.
I mean, there are very genuine concerns that he could be tortured or abused or somehow persecuted.

Their home countries, their countries where they had taken up residence before they were captured do not want them back.
So these are just one of the many challenges that the Pentagon is trying to face as they clear the numbers.

Now Human Rights Watch - a spokesman for Human Rights Watch today put out a statement celebrating this decision, saying it's the first time that a court has stopped the Pentagon from transferring one of these detainees back to where it wanted them to go.

This is a temporarily blocking, a temporary injunction.

courts.
